abstracts.cdata!:
The Leyte Luzon Geothermal
            Project's overall project outcome is rated as
            marginally unsatisfactory mainly because a) National Power
            Corporation has maintained its precarious financial
            situation and the objective of the strengthening the
            financial viability of the project entities has not been
            achieved; and b) the high cost of meeting the project's
            physical and environmental objectives was a contributing
            factor to this situation. The lessons learned from this
            project include: 1) While fast-track BOT
            (build-operate-transfer) projects have proved crucial in
            alleviating power shortages, the economic efficiency of
            individual private investments should be improved with due
            consideration for a cohesive sector approach and
            rationalization of prices and risk-sharing arrangements
            within a competitive and transparent framework. 2) It may
            not be realistic to expect power projects developed with
            private funds under the "fast-tracked" Independent
            Power Producer (IPP) Program to be least costly in the
            "traditional sense." 3) The high cost of the IPP
            Program has been a contributing factor to the failure of the
            project. Such an outcome indicates the need for sufficient
            risk analysis or management in a highly uncertain operating
            environment. 4) The use of a "rate of return on
            assets" target for financial performance is
            inappropriate for a company or sector with a very large and
            lumpy investment program. 5) Quality at entry is a critical
            success factor for project implementation.

729289.trustfund: TF021371-LEYTE GEOTHERMAL (NPC COMPON.),TF032472-PHILIPPINES - LEYTE GEOTHERMAL PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
World Bank guarantees broaden capital
            market access : the National Power Corporation -
            Philippines, and Jordan Telecommunications Corporation  bond issues

abstracts.cdata!:
Over the past year, the Bank's
            guarantee program has supported two bond issues for state
            utilities: a 15-year, US$100 million issue by the
            Philippines' National Power Corporation (NPC), launched
            in July 1994, and a 7-year, US$50 million issue by Jordan
            Telecommunications Corporation (TCC), scheduled to launch
            this month. This note analyzes the respective project
            guarantees, and discusses each project financing, indicating
            the maturity and pricing obtained with the support of the
            Bank's guarantee program are, for both issues,
            significantly better than those which could be achieved
            without the Bank's support. Putting the NPC and TCC
            issues into a global capital market context, developing
            country borrowers took advantage of historically-low
            interest rates and launched a record number of bonds in 1992-1993.

            Jordan Telecommunications Corporation  bond issues
